data.title: Allow Opening Symlink Directories
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. "Open Folder" -> select a symlink/shortcut folder
2. Silently fails

Opening a local folder containing the linked folder works and allows browsing down into the linked folder.

I have this file in my project tree and it is part of a stack trace. I navigate to the file by clicking a link that is located in the **Debug Console** panel.

data.title: ESLint multi root issues
data.body:
Things that need to be redone for ESLint multi root setups:

- create eslintrc file should ask for the folder or better get smarter and know what to do.
- folder qualification. Currently ESLint makes all pathes relative to the workspace folder in error messages to make them easier readable. With multi folder we either need to make them absolute or have an alias per folder in cases we have same workspace folder names.
- send an event when the multi folder setup has changed.

data.body: Two smoke test builds that run on Jun 15 left chromedriver.js running after it. They should be killed instead once smoke test is finished.

data.title: String enums are not recognized by intellisense (TypeScript 2.4.0 + Latest vscode)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file for newly introduced string enum e.g. test.enum.ts with such content:
```
export enum DefaultImages {
  defaultMerchantHeader = "/assets/default_merchant_header.jpg"
}
```
2. Create another file where you import string enum and try to set variable with it e.g. logic.ts
`const test = DefaultImages.defaultMerchantHeader;`

While compilator doesn't complain and compiles code nicely (using angular-cli setup) vscode is highlighting the usage of string enum as not correct...

Screenshots:
http://imgur.com/0a5mqqO


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Untitled files needs to be saved or discarded when you open a folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise, Windows 10 Pro and openSUSE Tumbleweed (probably OS independent)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start with an empty workspace
2. Create a new file (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>N</kbd>)
3. Type something (don't save the file)
4. Open any Folder... (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>K</kbd> <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>O</kbd>)

What happens?

A prompt is displayed asking if I want to save the file:

![Confirm Dialog](http://i.imgur.com/x70JNug.png)

<kbd>Save</kbd> - Correctly assumes the folder that you are opening
<kbd>Don't Save</kbd> - Discard the file
<kbd>Cancel</kbd> - Leave the file as is, folder will not be open

Desired behavior: 

There should be a way to "bind" the unsaved file to a folder without saving it. My suggestion is that instead of the Confirmation Dialog, "Untitled" files are automatically moved to the folder context.

Extra notes: 

Currently I can't find a way to bind untitled files to a folder context or even to different window. Drag and drop between windows does not work either.

The new behavior would be very welcome for users that uses vscode to take notes. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

```json
"window.reopenFolders": "all"
```

Is not working properly, because if I close all VS Code windows and I open again VS Code I get empty window, I call it untitled project, because there's nothing.

data.title: Electron  global variable error
Applying workspace settings for multiple folders requires multiple settings.json files
data.body:
When two folders or more are open in the same workspace and the view is split, displaying one file on the left from folder A and another file on the right from folder B, the settings.json file is only applied to the file in folder A when you create a new settings.json file with the palette:

- CTRL + SHFT + P
- Preference: Open workspace settings

**settings.json**

```
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite default and user settings.
{
     "editor.wordWrap": "on",
      "files.autoSave": "onFocusChange",
      "editor.fontSize": 13
}
```

I don;t know if this is by design, but for now, I have to copy the settings.json file from folder A to folder B to have the same font size in the editor on both open files. One would expect to have settings like these applied to all open folders by default.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insider (64 bit)
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:: [StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45028263/setting-editor-fontsize-for-multiple-folders-in-vs-code)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Code isn't recognizing keywords in C#

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:
After installing VS Code, writing any keywords with language set to C#.
It will not recognize majority of them (int, bool, public, etc).
Setting language to C++ makes it realize those keywords once again, though.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Edit: I just forgot to add some semicolons in places. Newbie programmer :P

data.title: Added Enabled View to Extension Viewlet
data.body:
Addresses #22866

Added Enabled action to extensions viewlet
Added "Extensions: Show Enabled Extensions" action to workbench
Set showing enabled in extensions to default view when opening extensions viewlet

data.title: Add markdown preview update timeout setting.
data.body:
Currently the markdown preview updates instantly and constantly. On slow computers this leads to lag and if images are embedded they tend to flicker as they are reloaded all the time.

It would be helpful if there were an option to only update the preview after no inputs have occurred for a set amount of milliseconds (usually i use 300 in web applications i write). Of course ideally this time can directly be customized to account for individual typing speeds and preferences.

data.title: Respect file order when opening files from command line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.11.8-100.fc24.x86_64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|contextualduplicate|lafe|0.2.0|
|MDTools|seanmcbreen|1.0.1|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open multiple files in deep folders from command lines, for example: `code a/test.txt b/test.txt c/test.txt`
2. VS Code opens those files in arbitrary order.

Would you please update this behavior, to make VS Code open those files in the order they are arranged?

Thank you,

---

***Edited***

It fails with opening files from within a same folder too.
